metadata.synopsis: Four high school kids discover an old video game console and are drawn into the game's jungle setting, literally becoming the adult avatars they chose. What they discover is that you don't just play Jumanji - you must survive it. To beat the game and return to the real world, they'll have to go on the most dangerous adventure of their lives, discover what Alan Parrish left 20 years ago, and change the way they think about themselves - or they'll be stuck in the game forever.

reviews: By the time the end credits roll everyone are better off than when the movie started... except maybe the audience who deserve more than a handful of laughs and warmed over 90s nostalgia.
Back and forth banter is largely amusing, even if the script insists upon containing wholesome themes.
The production values and special effects are top-notch and the cast is obviously having a good time, the avatars now possessed with different personalities.
A spunky ball of energetic entertainment, with a whole lot of fun and heartwarming moments.
You might not have thought you needed another Jumanji movie, but once you see it, it might be difficult to imagine ever not wanting it to exist.
Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle is a harmless, well-meaning, spirited, and perhaps overly polished adventure tale that I can almost guarantee you kids of a certain age will really take to.
Everyone involved in Jumanji is so completely annoying. It's a wretched remake that exists for no particular reason.
Kasdan knows this is all about his stars' charisma, and keeps them bouncing off each other in pleasing ricochets.
It works as entertainment and it is respectful to the first installment without falling into the error of trying to make a remake. [Full Review in Spanish]
A quick and autoparodic script that helps demystifying archetypes through the fun interpretations of the casting.[Full Review in Spanish]
This sequel has enough razzle-dazzle and laughs to make for a fun family entertainer.
Enjoyable and undemanding entertainment.
It's probably better than it has any right to be, gleefully exploring its jungle video game concept while cleverly updating the concept for a whole new audience.
Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle does not want to make a lasting impression, it just wants to divert your attention for a couple of hours. And at that, it is successful. Marginally.
Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle doesn't take advantage of its premise, instead going for lazy lowbrow humor and not much else.
Some very lightweight entertainment: you get in, you get some action, you get some laughs, you get out.
The movie gets a lot of material by mixing up the genders of the characters in the movie and it is pretty funny.
The film is at its strongest when it's not taking itself too seriously, with plenty of laugh out loud moments driving a smart and entertaining action adventure.
The "no sequel" that barely works due to a great cast and decent effects. It could have exploited its premise a lot more than it did. [Full review in Spanish].

It's not a particularly sophisticated movie, but it really does have something for everyone - some great action set pieces, plenty of physical comedy, jokes both silly and smart, some charming awkward romance stuff, you name it.
publisher: data-qa="review-critic-publication">Reel Talk with Chuck and Pam
